s.text: My skill at writing software, I believe, is God-given.
Microsoft's Windows 95 operating system contains more than 10 million lines of code, or instructions.
After developers write a few lines of code, we test it for bugs and sit down with our testers to imagine all the ways the program will be used.
My legendary success at squashing bugs, I believe, is the result of my tendency to write buggy code.
My legendary success at squashing bugs, I believe, is the result of my tendency to write buggy code.
(My favorite tester routinely yanked the power cord out of the computer during Outlook operations to see how the program handled loss of power.)
(My favorite tester routinely yanked the power cord out of the computer during Outlook operations to see how the program handled loss of power.)
(My favorite tester routinely yanked the power cord out of the computer during Outlook operations to see how the program handled loss of power.)
My legendary success at squashing bugs, I believe, is the result of my tendency to write buggy code.
My legendary success at squashing bugs, I believe, is the result of my tendency to write buggy code.
My legendary success at squashing bugs, I believe, is the result of my tendency to write buggy code.
You are always only a few late nights away from perfection.
There I was, late one night in the Microsoft software factory, furiously exterminating some of the skankier bugs from my areas of Outlook 97, our e-mail program.
As developers kill the bugs, they incorporate the solutions into a daily "build" of the program and test the build to make certain the solutions don't cause additional bugs.
But we make the absolutely smallest necessary change to kill the bug so that the other parts of the system can continue to work, oblivious to the chaos around them.
Preventing developers from adding features is not as easy as it sounds.
Having found a bug, it's not easy to find what caused it.
In this case, reproduction would be easy.
But, as Shuman can tell you, it's easy to write bugs into simple, short programs, like one designed to find a single word in a sentence.
The Y2K bug is a very bad bug; the one tiny decision about how to express dates can bring a whole program to a screeching halt.
Preventing developers from adding features is not as easy as it sounds.
Preventing developers from adding features is not as easy as it sounds.
Preventing developers from adding features is not as easy as it sounds.
Preventing developers from adding features is not as easy as it sounds.
Preventing developers from adding features is not as easy as it sounds.
Preventing developers from adding features is not as easy as it sounds.
Why shouldn't Outlook 97 be able to handle appointments in specified conference rooms in future millenniums?
